Bitcoin ร่วงลงเหลือ $55,000 บน Bithumb หลังจากเกิดความผิดพลาดในการจ่ายรางวัลภายในระบบ เนื่องจากเว็บไซต์แลกเปลี่ยนโอนเงินเข้าบัญชีผู้ใช้ผิดพลาด โดยให้ 2,000 BTC แทนที่จะเป็นเงินสกุลวอนเพียง 2,000 วอน แม้ว่าจะไม่มีการโอน Bitcoin ผ่าน on-chain แต่ยอดเงินหลอกในบัญชีทางบัญชีทำให้ผู้ใช้รีบขายออก ส่งผลให้ราคาดิ่งลงต่ำกว่าตลาดอื่นถึง 15.8% Bithumb ระบุว่าสามารถระบุและหยุดการซื้อขายในบัญชีที่ได้รับผลกระทบภายในเวลาประมาณ 5 นาที ทำให้ราคากลับสู่ภาวะปกติ ทางเว็บไซต์ยืนยันว่าเหตุการณ์นี้ไม่เกี่ยวข้องกับการถูกแฮกหรือการละเมิดความปลอดภัย และยืนยันว่าเงินของลูกค้ายังคงปลอดภัยอยู่

EN

Bitcoin crashed to $55,000 on the South Korean exchange Bithumb following an internal accounting error. The exchange mistakenly credited users with 2,000 BTC each instead of a small fiat reward, creating millions of dollars in phantom balances. Although no Bitcoin moved on-chain, the inflated internal ledgers triggered a panic sell-off, causing the BTC/KRW pair to trade 15.8% lower than on other exchanges. Bithumb managed to restrict trading on affected accounts and normalize prices within approximately five minutes. The exchange emphasized that the incident was not a hack and that customer assets remain secure, confirming that its liquidation prevention systems operated correctly.

Key Points

  • Bithumb accidentally credited users with 2,000 BTC instead of a small reward, causing a flash crash.
  • The price of Bitcoin dropped to $55,000 on the exchange, 15.8% lower than global market rates.
  • No Bitcoin moved on-chain; the error was confined to Bithumb's internal ledger.
  • Bithumb restored normal prices within five minutes and confirmed no security breach occurred.

Article

Bitcoin crashed to $55,000 on Bithumb after exchange accidentally airdropped users 2,000 BTC An internal reward distribution mistake briefly sent bitcoin prices sharply lower on South Korea’s Bithumb exchange after users were mistakenly credited with large phantom balances. Feb 6, 2026, 4:14 p.m. Bitcoin BTC $65,998.81 suffered a flash crash to $55,000 on South Korean exchange Bithumb this week after what appears to have been a major internal accounting error. Bithumb mistakenly credited users with 2,000 BTC each instead of a small reward worth 2,000 Korean won (about $1.50), according to a blog post on Friday. STORY CONTINUES BELOW The result was tens of millions of dollars’ worth of phantom bitcoin appearing in hundreds of user accounts. No bitcoin was moved onchain, and inflated balances existed only in Bithumb's internal ledger. Users who suddenly saw enormous balances wasted little time trying to sell, triggering a sharp selloff on Bithumb’s BTC/KRW pair, sending prices 15.8% below other exchanges. At one point, BTC traded at 81 million won ($55,000) while prices elsewhere remained relatively stable. Bithumb said it identified the abnormal transactions through internal controls and restricted trading in the affected accounts shortly after the incident. The exchange said prices on its platform normalized within about five minutes and that its liquidation prevention system operated as intended, preventing any cascading forced liquidations linked to the price movement. The company added that the incident was not related to an external hack or security breach and that customer assets remain secure.
